ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a solid abstract, bibliography and plan for my thesis as I head into the writing portion during second semester.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: This course is very good at breaking down the research process week by week, and students get regular practice summarizing their topic, writing abstracts, and presenting proposals to outside faculty. Prof. Caldeira and the TAs are all very supportive and willing to help you think through any challenges as they arise throughout the research process! Weaknesses: Sometimes, the weekly workload can feel high; it can be tricky to find a balance between your own research and the required readings for class. Weekly reading responses try to bring them together, but sometimes these two components of the class - core reading and personal research - felt disjointed.
We received a lot of different feedback from guest critics from a wide variety of disciplines which was very helpful

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of Miro was incredibly helpful to re-create the experience of being in the studio, pinning up images, and seeing your peers' work.
I would have liked to use the breakout rooms more often.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you have a good idea of the topic(s) that you want to pursue for your senior thesis, then this is a great class (and a requirement if you want to do an independent urban studies/architecture thesis). The course is super helpful breaking down the research process and creating weekly assignments to work towards an abstract, project proposal, and presentation slide deck. The individual time and support you get with Prof. Caldeira and the TAs is also amazing - they are all invaluable resources to help you develop your project.
Yes, it is a helpful way to gain structure and receive a lot of feedback for such a daunting project like a thesis. This class made it more collaborative and duable.
